title: The Pandemic’s Mental Toll, and Does Telehealth Work? Your Health, Quickly, Episode 1
intro: Hosts Josh Fischman and Tanya Lewis explore the pandemic’s mental health toll on teens and young adults. They also delve into the effectiveness of telehealth, which has been booming since the start of the pandemic.

transcript.author: Tanya Lewis
transcript.text: : Hi. I'm Tanya Lewis.

transcript.author: Josh Fischman
transcript.text: : And I'm Josh Fishman. We're Scientific American's senior health editors.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Welcome to the show formally known as COVID, Quickly.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Now it's the first episode of a new show that's about COVID, but also a lot more.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : We're entering the third year of our podcast. Wow. And the fourth year of COVID. The disease is still here and it's still serious, but life for everyone is a little bit different now. So instead of just pandemic news, we want to highlight other health news, too, and demystify medical research in a way you can use to stay healthy.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : We're calling the show Your Health, Quickly.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : We'll keep covering important updates on COVID. But now we're also going to bring you the latest research on other infectious diseases like the flu.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : And noninfectious ones like cancer and heart disease, reproductive health and mental health.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : We'll also discuss the latest science on preventive health, nutrition and much more. We hope you enjoy the show.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : We should probably tell people what we're talking about today.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Okay. So our first topic is still somewhat COVID related, but it's something we haven't really talked about that much. The pandemic's impact on mental health.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : And we'll discuss ways that all across medicine, telehealth is changing how care is being delivered, even for things like cancer and diabetes.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : When the pandemic was at its worst, it made sense for us to focus on the risks of dying from the virus itself. But thanks to effective vaccines and treatments, we're in a different place now. So now we can start to address some of the impacts the past few years have had on our well-being.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : That's a good point. All of the lockdowns and the isolation have certainly taken a toll on us mentally.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : They really have. I know I found it hard to avoid seeing friends and family during the worst COVID surges on top of the constant fear of getting sick. And it's not just anecdotal. There's mounting evidence that these mental strains are widespread.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Tell me about it. What do these data show?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Well, a nonprofit called the Kaiser Family Foundation has been tracking mental health throughout the pandemic with an ongoing poll. In early 2021, the data showed that as many as four in ten adults had symptoms of anxiety or depression, compared with only one in ten adults before the pandemic. That fraction is now closer to three in ten, but that's still a lot of depressed, anxious people.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : That means every third person I walk by on the street has some of these issues. What are some of the ways that this has played out?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : People have reported problems with sleeping and eating, and they started drinking and using drugs more and existing chronic health problems got worse. To find out more, I talked to the lead author of that report on mental health.

transcript.author: Nirmita Panchal
transcript.text: : My name is Nirmata Panchal, and I'm a senior policy analyst at the Kaiser Family Foundation.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Can you just tell me a little bit about what some of the major findings were?

transcript.author: Panchal
transcript.text: : So as we know, during the pandemic, people have experienced a number of different changes and disruptions. For some that may be increased isolation. For others, it may be job loss and experiences such as housing and food insecurity.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Can you talk a little bit more specifically about the impact on children and young adults in particular?

transcript.author: Panchal
transcript.text: : When we looked at the young adult population and during the pandemic, they have experienced a number of disruptions during a time that's already filled with a great deal of transition. Transitioning to college and then experiencing college closures in light of the pandemic. Perhaps they may be experiencing job loss or a reduction in their work hours. And what we knew leading up to the pandemic is that a large share of young adults were not receiving mental health care.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : That's really tough on that age group.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : A lot of these kids had to miss out on major milestones like graduations and birthday parties.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Yeah. So, you know, like, when you're 16, that could be a big valley in your life.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : When you're that age, when you're a teenager, it's so important and you just want to share in that with all your friends. As you probably saw, there was a recent CDC report that found record high levels of sadness and suicidal thoughts among teenage girls. Can you talk about that and why girls may be particularly at risk?

transcript.author: Panchal
transcript.text: : Some of the data we've seen during the pandemic has found that adverse experiences at home for a lot of adolescents, they tend to be more elevated among young females compared to their male peers. At the same time, we've also found rates of self-harm are increasing more quickly among young females.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : I'm wondering whether you think that these mental health impacts are likely to persist long term?

transcript.author: Panchal
transcript.text: : Yeah, that's a great question. I think, you know, while we don't have those answers yet, we do know that many mental health conditions develop during adolescence. And if they go untreated, they can persist into adulthood and they can limit quality of life.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : One of the points that Nirmita made was that you really need to address this in schools. So schools are like a natural place for connecting kids with mental health services.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Which of course is going to require local school districts and states to pony up money for schools.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : You can't just expect kids to be so isolated and deal with all of these stresses and not have there be some kind of long term fallout. ---

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : There's one change that we all made during the pandemic that looks like it's going to stick around, and that's telehealth. Using a video or audio connection for a checkup with your doctor.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Before COVID hit, telehealth was pretty rare. Insurance companies didn't reimburse health care workers for doing it, and various regulations required what they called an in-person relationship.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : But then in 2020, we suddenly had to keep our distance to avoid infecting others. So those regulations were relaxed and telehealth boomed. The boom spread throughout medicine, including cancer care, endocrinology and a bunch of other specialties.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : How big a boom are you talking about?

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : A pretty big one, Tanya. At Stanford Health Care in California, telehealth shot up from about 3 percent of visits before the pandemic to about 70 percent during it. Now, a lot of health care networks are saying that it's settled in at about 10 to 30 percent of all their patient visits.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : But how do you do cancer care over video? Don't you have to show up in person for chemo and x-rays?

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Well, that's an excellent question. And you're not the only one curious about that. Our colleague, reporter Lydia Denworth, wanted to know about this, too. So I asked her to stop by and explain. Maybe you should start by telling everyone who you are, Lydia.

transcript.author: Lydia Denworth
transcript.text: : I'm Lydia Denworth. I'm a science journalist and I'm a contributing editor for Scientific American for the magazine. And I am also now the new columnist for the Science of Health column.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Good to have you here. Now, you yourself have done some telehealth, haven't you?

transcript.author: Denworth
transcript.text: : I did. And like many other people in this country during the pandemic, I had some sessions with my psychiatrist, but had to be by video through telehealth instead of in-person. That made me curious. As you know, the pandemic is beginning to abate in from people's lives about how telehealth is actually being used.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : I can imagine that talk therapy, psychotherapy lends itself to telehealth. But you found some surprises in other medical specialties, didn't you?

transcript.author: Denworth
transcript.text: : I did. But it turns out that things like cancer care also are making quite substantial use of telehealth in places.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : How can you care for a cancer patient through a video link?

transcript.author: Denworth
transcript.text: : You usually have to go to the doctor quite a lot and it turns out that you can cut out like a big chunk of those appointments, the ones that don't require things like an infusion for immunotherapy. So when you're talking to your doctor and checking in with your doctor, you can do those appointments virtually and save everybody some time.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Does that work as well as getting in your car and driving to your doctor's office or to a hospital?

transcript.author: Denworth
transcript.text: : It absolutely does. There are a lot of medicine that is still a conversation between a patient and a doctor. There are some some specialties that are finding there are real advantages to talking to people in their homes or endocrinologists who treat diabetes can also see people at home and get more kind of clues to what their home life is like, what their diet might be like at home, and how things are going.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : Lydia does make some good points. But I do wonder how these virtual visits compare to in-person visits for quality of care.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : It turns out that they actually stack up pretty well., Tanya. There have been a few studies checking up on care. Nearly 90 percent of the time a virtual diagnosis agreed with a later diagnosis made in person, researchers reported in the journal JAMA Network Open last year, and another study of more than 500,000 patients found equal or better outcomes for telehealth across 13 of 16 primary care measures such as management of diabetes and getting signed up for flu shots.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : That's pretty good. I guess another advantage is in rural areas where your doctor can be hours away, but virtually you can save all that time and money commuting, and you don't have to take a whole day off work.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : Lydia goes into this in a lot more detail there in her article on Telehealth for SciAm, which you can read online starting in the middle of March and in the April print issue. Your Health Quickly is produced and edited by Jeff DelViscio, Tulika Bose and Kelso Harper.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : The show is one of Scientific American's Science, Quickly podcasts. Subscribe to Science, Quickly wherever you get your podcasts.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: : And don't forget to go to SciAm.com for updated and in-depth health news.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: : We'll be back in two weeks. Talk to you then.
